title: OEDA Plot Toggle Test
text:
Test Plot with Custom knit_print Method
This should automatically generate both light and dark versions and toggle between them:





Test scatter plot






Manual Test (Alternative if above doesn’t work)
If the automatic method doesn’t work, here’s a manual approach:

title: OEDA Standards Guide
text: Website Under Construction

title: Clean Renderings Test
text:
Code
# Create a simple base plot
base_scatter <- ggplot(mtcars, aes(x = wt, y = mpg, color = factor(cyl))) +
  geom_point(size = 3, alpha = 0.8) +
  labs(
    title = "Vehicle Weight vs MPG",
    x = "Weight (1000 lbs)",
    y = "Miles per gallon",
    color = "Cylinders"
  ) +
  scale_color_manual(values = c("red", "blue", "green"))

print("Base plot created successfully")


[1] "Base plot created successfully"

title: Clean Renderings Test
text:
Code
# Create a simple base plot
base_scatter <- ggplot(mtcars, aes(x = wt, y = mpg, color = factor(cyl))) +
  geom_point(size = 3, alpha = 0.8) +
  labs(
    title = "Vehicle Weight vs MPG",
    x = "Weight (1000 lbs)",
    y = "Miles per gallon",
    color = "Cylinders"
  ) +
  scale_color_manual(values = c("red", "blue", "green"))

print("Base plot created successfully")


[1] "Base plot created successfully"

title: Clean Renderings Test
section: Step 2: Test Basic Renderings (No Custom Themes)
text:
Step 2: Test Basic Renderings (No Custom Themes)


Code
# Light version - red points
ggplot(mtcars, aes(x = wt, y = mpg)) +
  geom_point(color = "red", size = 3) +
  labs(title = "LIGHT MODE - Red Points") +
  theme_minimal()

# Dark version - blue points  
ggplot(mtcars, aes(x = wt, y = mpg)) +
  geom_point(color = "blue", size = 3) +
  labs(title = "DARK MODE - Blue Points") +
  theme_minimal()





Basic renderings test - should show different colors







Basic renderings test - should show different colors

title: Clean Renderings Test
text:
Step 3: Test With OEDA Themes


Code
# Light version with OEDA light theme
base_scatter + theme_oeda_light()

# Dark version with OEDA dark theme
base_scatter + theme_oeda_dark()





OEDA themes test







OEDA themes test

title: Clean Renderings Test
section: Step 4: Test Simple R Base Graphics
text:
Step 4: Test Simple R Base Graphics


Code
# Light version
par(bg = "white", fg = "black")
plot(mtcars$wt, mtcars$mpg, main = "LIGHT MODE", col = "red", pch = 16)

# Dark version
par(bg = "black", fg = "white", col.main = "white", col.lab = "white", col.axis = "white")
plot(mtcars$wt, mtcars$mpg, main = "DARK MODE", col = "cyan", pch = 16)





Base R graphics test







Base R graphics test

title: Clean Renderings Test
text:
What Should Happen:

Step 2: You should see RED points in light mode, BLUE points in dark mode
Step 3: You should see the same plot with different OEDA themes
Step 4: You should see a white background plot in light mode, black background in dark mode

title: Clean Renderings Test
text:
Debugging Information:
Toggle between light and dark modes using the theme switcher. If you see:

Both plots showing: renderings isn’t working at all
No plots showing: There’s a CSS conflict hiding everything

Same plot in both modes: renderings is working but not switching
Correct behavior: renderings is working perfectly!

title: Buttons
Buttons
Buttons
Buttons
Buttons
Buttons
Buttons
text:
Primary: Use for the main action users should take (Submit, Save, Continue)
Secondary: Use for secondary actions (Cancel, Back, Reset)

Outlined: Use when you need a button that’s less prominent than secondary
Action buttons: Use semantic colors for specific actions (Success for downloads, Warning for alerts, etc.)





Limit to one primary button per section
Use consistent spacing between buttons
Always include descriptive text, not just icons
Ensure sufficient color contrast for accessibility
Test button interactions in both light and dark modes





All buttons include proper ARIA labels
Color is not the only way to convey information
Focus states are clearly visible
Disabled states are properly indicated to screen readers

title: Buttons
Value Box Cards
Value Box Cards
text: These cards replicate the look and feel of Quarto Dashboard value boxes but work in: - ✅ Quarto Websites (like this site) - ✅ Regular HTML pages - ✅ R Markdown documents - ✅ Any Bootstrap-based project

title: Value Box Cards
Value Box Cards
Value Box Cards
Value Box Cards
Value Box Cards
text:
value-box-primary - Main KPIs, revenue, primary metrics
value-box-success - Positive trends, goals achieved, systems healthy
value-box-danger - Negative trends, errors, alerts, problems
value-box-warning - Caution states, approaching limits, maintenance
value-box-info - Neutral information, general metrics, informational data





Always include direction: Use arrows (↑↓) or icons (bi-arrow-up/down)
Provide context: “vs last quarter”, “vs target”, “vs last week”
Use consistent formatting: Same decimal places, same comparison periods
Color coding: Green for positive, red for negative, gray for neutral





Mobile-first: Use responsive grid classes (col-sm-6 col-lg-3)
Consistent spacing: Add margin-bottom (mb-3) for proper spacing
Group related metrics: Place similar metrics together
Logical order: Most important metrics first (left to right, top to bottom)

title: Value Box Cards
Issues and Bugs to Fix
text:
Dark mode caption text color not updating with rest of text. This is done with #| fig-cap: "Title" chunk option.
Icon colors for light mode need lightening.
The oeda-logo-wide-light.svg needs to have whitespace removed from .svg file
Font matching from primary and wide logos need to be done. Fix in Affinity.
New icon files failing. Investigate. No icon in navbar.
cards page has non-working value box cards.

title: OEDA HTML Branding Demo
text:
This is a paragraph using the base font (Noto Sans Regular). If this text and the headings look correct, then the typography from _brand.yml is working as expected.


This section will test if we can embed one of the logos directly into the document body using the same path defined in _brand.yml.










NoteHybrid Approach: CSS + Renderings



This document uses a hybrid approach: - CSS classes (.light-content and .dark-content) for logos and HTML content - renderings: [light, dark] for ggplot2 plots and R graphics
This is necessary because Quarto’s renderings feature only works for plot outputs, not HTML content.








OEDA ICON





OEDA WIDE LOGO





OEDA VERTICAL LOGO







OEDA ICON





OEDA WIDE LOGO





OEDA DARK LOGO













Brand Color Swatches and Tints
